Randal with all his rush'd into the room; and new every hand conspired to free his under-Jaw from the Sharp eth of the raged Monster. But the Lady, whose heart meltd at the piecus Spectacle, was so zealous in this office of hu∣manity, that the Cat-a-mountain, prvok'd at her good∣natur'd diligence, leap'd suriously on her, and mounted three of her Hands and her two Noses, to such a barba∣reas
degree, that she was not fit to be shown publickly for the sp of three Weeks. The generous r, men wounded at this Spectacle than by all the scratches he had himself rei'd, charg'd the monster again wish the utmost intripidity, and rescued his mangled Mistress. Then (having taken her by the stand, and given it a gentle grasp) he retreated with his eyes fixed upon her▪ and just as he left the room (in a l and tender ) thus breath'd forth his Soul: "Behold, all this have I "suffer'd for you".

Such, and medist was the first declaration of re, made on this eminent occasion by our Youthful Phi∣losepher. Nor was it ungently received by the simple and innocent indamira; who, hitherto unus'd to the soft. Pretistations fadering Slaves, had rather been won der'd at than belov'd and receiv'd but imperfect nations of that tender language, from the Addresses only of the black Prince or the Dwarf.

Martin, notwithstanding this unfortunate adventure, still pursu'd his wishes. His tters were now no more intercepted. Lindamira read them, and behav'd like other courteous dames when they receive those amrous Testimonials; conceal'd them from her Guardian, and
return'd the most engaging answers. In short, she was so far captivated as to resolve no longer to be gaz'd at like a public Beauty in her own. Assembly; but retire from the World, and become the Mistress of a nily.

But fate had so ordain'd, that Martin was not more enamour'd on Lindamira, than Indamera was on Martin. She, jealous that her Sister had the great∣est share in this conquest, resented that an equal application had not been made to herself she Lindamira to such a degree on this Subject, as made her promise to see Martin no more. But then again might Indamera be deem'd the unhappiest of Women, whom her Passion and Imprudence had robb'd of the sight of her yet shame caused her to reneval these harieties from her sister. And let the Reader judge here unhappy the ymph must be, who waseven de∣prived the universal Relief of a Selilequy. However, thus she thought, without bring allow'd to to any Greve or purling Stream.

Wretched Indamora! if Lindamira must never men ee Martin, Martin shall never again bless the Eyes of Indamera. Yet why d ay wretched, since my Rival
can nr my Lover without me? The pan that others in Absnce, from the thought of these ys that bless their Rirals, can never ing thy nor can they mrtify by making thee a Witness, without giving thee at the same time a share of their Endearments. Change then thy prceeding, Indamera; thy Jealousy must act a nw and unheard of part, an promote the interest of thy Rival, as the only may to the enjoyment of thy Lover.

From that moment she studied by all methods to ad∣vance her Sister's Amour, and in that her own. And thus there appear'd in these three Lovers as extraordinary a Conjunction of Passions as of Persons: Love had rcon∣eil'd himself to his mortal f, to Philosophy in Mar∣tin, and to jealousy in Indamera.

And new flourish'd the mour of Martin; success pvented his wishes, the Marriage was agreed on, and the day appointed. Sunday was the time, when Randal's absence farour'd their hopes, h on that day omitted taking the fresh air in the Fields: the ey of the door he always look with him. Crambe was ready laid at a convenient distance, who accommodated them with a Ladder of Repes. The
Ladder was thrown up, and the signal given at the Window Lindamira hasten'd to the alarm of Love, when behold a new disaster! as she was gtting out of the Win∣dow, the weight of her Body on one side, and that of In∣damera's on the other, unluckily caus'd them to stick in the midway: Lindamira hung with her coats stript up to the navel without, and Indamera in no less posture within. The Manteger, who for his gentleness was allowed to walk at large in the house, was so heighten'd of this sight, that he rush'd upon Indamera like a barbarous Ravisher. Indamera cried aloud for help.

Martin to revenge this insolent attempt of a Rpe n his Wedding-day. The ustful Menster, driven from our double led into the middle of the room, pursu'd by the ralereus and indignant Martin Three times the het Mant, frighted at the furious menaces of his antagenist, made a circle round the chamber, and three times the swift-feeted Martin pursu'd him. The caught up the ern of a unicorn, which ay ready for the entertainment of the curious spectator, and ran∣ishing it ever his head in airy circles, hurl'd it against the hairy Sen of Hanniman; who wrink ling his brown forehead, and gnashing his teeth in indignation, steep'd
low: the herny Lance just ras'd his left Shoulder, and stuck into the tapestry hangings. Provok'd at this, the grin∣ning offspring of Hanniman caught up the pointed er of an ntelope, and aim'd a blow against his undismay Adversary. Our heroic Lover, who held his hat before him like a shield, receiv'd the weapon full on the crown; it pierc'd the beaver, and gave a small rent to his breeches. Then the human slung with mighty violence the hinder feet of an Elk, which hit the bestial combatant full on the nether Jaw. He reel'd, but soon recovering, and his skill in War lying rather in the close fight then in projectile weapons, he endeavour'd to close with him: forth with assailing him behind unawares, he clamber'd up his back, and pluck'd up by the roots a mighty grasp of hair∣but Martin soon dismounted him, and kept him at a distance. Love not only inspired his breast with Courage, but gave double strength to his sines; he hear'd up the han of a prodigious Sea-monster; which when the chalt'ring Champion behold, he no less furious, wielded the Pendious Thigh-bone of a Giant. And now they stood oppos'd to each other, like the dread Explain of the seven-fold shield and the redoubted hector. The Thigh-bone miss'd its aim; but the hand of the Sea-monster deseended directly
on the head of the Sylvan Rarisher. The Monster chatter'd horrible; he stretch'd his quir'ring Limbs on the floor; and eternal Sleep leck'd fast his Eye-lids.

The lady from the window, like another elen from the ejan wall, was witness of the Combat caused by her own Beauty. She saw with what gracefulness her Here enter'd the Lists, admir'd his activity and courage in the Combat, and was a joyful witness of his triumph: She gave a spring from the window, and with open arms and Segs embraced the Neck and Shoulders of her Champion. Our Philosopher receiv'd her with his Face turn'd modestly from her, and in that manner convey'd her into the Street. He call'd a Chair with all haste, but no Chairman would take her; which obliged him to bear his extra ordinary burden till he found a Coach, in which he carried her off; and was happily united to her that very evening, by a Reverend. Clergyman in the Het, in the holy Bands of Matrimony.

DIV1.HEAD: CHAP. XIV.

Q.P: Of the strange and never to be parallel'd Process at Law upon the Marriage of Scriblerus, and the pleadings of the Livecates.

DIV1.P: But mesis, who delights in the best laid designs of upid, maieously contrired the means to make these three Lovers unhappy.▪ Ssner had the Master of the Shew nlice of flight, but he seiz'd on the Boh mian Ladies by arrant; and not content with having recover'd the pesin of them, reselr'd to open all the Sis of the Saw upon. Martin▪ So he instantly went to counsel to adrise upon all possible methods of Revenge.

The first point he preceed on was the Property of his Monster, and the question prepeunded was An Sewi posin, in vitis Dominis, Matrimonium contrahere?“Whether Slaves could marry without the consent of their Master?” To this he was answer'd in the Affirmative, but told at the same time “That An Seus Matrimonio imit a Demini obsequie?the Marriage did not exempt them from Servitude.”

This put him in no small hpi of having Martin added to his show, and acquiring a property in his Bedily issue
by the Ladies. But his joy was seen dasn'd, when he was in∣form'd that since Martin was a free man, An Liberi sequntur Conditionem Patris, an Matris“The Chil∣dren must follow the nition of the ather: or, that in died, if they were o follow that of their Mother, the Case would be the same, there being no Slavery in England.”

Then his Counsel judged it more advisable to plead for a issolution of the Marriage, upon the impossibility of Conjugal dus in the ife. But then the anen Law al∣low'd a Jriennial ehabitation; which intirely ruin'd this project also. Besides it was evident by the same. Law, that "Monstrosity could not incapacitate from Marriage," witness the Case of Hermaphrodites, who are allow'd "facultation Conjugü, provided they make Election be∣fore the Parish Priest, in what for they will act, and take an a never to perform in the other Capacity." Sanchez, Hostiens. Sybrest.It was consulted whether Martin should not be per∣mitted to take away his Wife since, upon his so doing "he might be sed for a hape upon the Body of her sis∣ter, there being plainly the four Conditions of aidentia, Causa Litidinis, Traduclio ad Lum, Mulier honesta.Rase".
But then again they consider'd, that Martin might an∣swer, he claim'd nothing but his own; and if another per∣son had fix'd herself to his Wife, he must not for that cause be debarr'd the use of his Property.

Yet still, upon the same head of Martins possessing his ouse, a Suit might be derised in the name of Lindamira, on this account; x or non tenetur vivere cum vie Concubinam tenenteThat a "Wife was not obliged to live with a oncubine, and such her Sister Indamora must be accounted to Martin from the common acs, ampplxus, cohabitalieproofs." So this too it was replied, that the Lawerder'd the Wife to rside with the Husband if there were sufficient security given to ex∣pell the concubine. So Martin might say he was ready to accomplish his part of the covenant, if his Wife would per∣form hers, and consent to the An tender Incisionem pali? Sanchez de MatrimonioIncision. But this being an impossibility on the side of the Wife, it cou'd no way exacted of the Husband.

It length Randal, bring vax'd to the Heart, to have been so long and so quaintly disappointed, determin'd to commence a Suit against martin for Bigamy and
Incest. Mean while he left n Artifice or Address un try'd to prplux the unhappy Phylosopher: He even centriv'd with infinite cunning, to alienate Indameras affections from him, and debach'd her into an intrique with a creature of his even, the black Prince; whom he secretly cau∣sed to marry her, while her Sister was asle.

Wereupon Martin was reduc'd to turn Plaintiff, and commenc'd a Suit in the Spiritual Court against the black Prince, for Cohabitation with his said Wife. He was advis'd to insist upon a nw point, (viz.) “That Lindamira and Indamora together made up but one lawful Wife.”

The Monster-master, further to distress Martin, forc'd Sin∣damira to petition for ment, pendente: which was no sooner allow'd her by the Court, but he obliged her to alledge, that, “it was not sufficient to maintain both her∣self and her Sister; and if her Sister perish'd, she could not live with the dead Body about her.”

Martin now began to repent that he not executed a resolution he formerly conceiv'd, of marrying to Indamora, as an Expedient to have made all secure. Moreover, it was insisted on; that the other also had a right to Miment, “because, if Martins Wife should prove with, the said Sister must
necesarily perform the offices of a Wife, in contributing to the Sutrition and Gastalien of the said child.”. A Jury of Phy∣sicians being impannel'd, declar'd, that as to. Sutrition they were doubtful, whether any bleed of Lindamira circulae through Indmera: But as to Gastalien, it was crideny true. And upon this, Martin was order'd to allow lliment to both, the black Prince appearing insevent.
Then the Court proceeded to the Trial. And as both the Cause and the pleadings ar of an extraordinary. Nature, me think fit here to insert them at length.
Dr. Penny-feather thus pleaded for. Martinus Scriberus the Plaintiff.

DIV2.HEAD: Dr. Penny-feather.

P.Q:
“”I appear before your Honour in behalf of Martinus Scri∣blerus, Batchelor of Physick, in a Complaint against Ebn-Hai-Paw-Ww, commonly call'd the black Prince of Mene∣mtapa; Inasmuch as the said Ebn-Hai-Paw-Ww, hath maliciously, forcibly, and unlawly seiz'd ravish'd, and detain'd Lindamira-Indamora, the Wife of the said. Martin, and the Body of the said Lindamira-Indamora from time to time ever since, hath wickedly, lwdly, and
indecently us'd, handled, and rib entreated. And in or∣der to make this his ill any more lasting, hath presum'd to marry this our Wife, pretending to give his wickedness the Sanction of a Saw. And forasmuch as the adulterer▪ doth not dny the fact, but insists upon his said marriage as lawful, we cannot open the Case more plainly to your Honour, than by answering his Reasons, which, indeed to mention, is to cenful.

“”He maintains noless an absurdity than this, that One is Two; and that Lindamira-Indamora, the indivi∣dual wife of the Plaintiff, is not one, but two Persons: and that the said Ebn-Hai-Paw-Waw is not married to Lin∣damira, the Wife of the said. Martin, but to his own lawful Wife Indamora, another individual person distinct from the said Lindamira, the join'd to her by a strong Ligament of Nature.

DIV2.P: In answer whereunto we shall prove three things: “”First, that the said Lindamira-Indamora, now our lawful Wife makes but one individual Person.

P.Q: “”Secondly, That if they made two individual Persons, yet they constitute but one Wife.

“”Thirdly, That supposing they made two individual Per∣sons,
and Hives each lawfully marry'd to her own band, yet Prince Ebn-Hai-Paw- hath no right to detain Lindamira our lawful wedded wife, on pretence of being married to Indamora.

“”As to the first point: It will be necessary to determine the constituent Principle and Ence of Individuality, which, in respect to mankind, we take to be one simple identical ul in one simple Identical Body. The individuality, sameness or identity of the body, is not determin'd (as some vainly imagine) by one head, and a certain number of arms, legs, and other mem∣bers; but in one simple or member of Generation▪ Let us search profane History, and we shall find Geryon with three heads, and Briars with an Hundred hands. Let us search sacred History, and we meet with one of the Sons of the Giants with six Fingers to each hand, and six s to each Foot; yet none ever accounted Ge∣ryon or Briarus more than one Person: and give us leave to say, the wife of the said Geryon would have had a good action against any women who should have espous'd themselves to the other two heads of that Monarch. The Reason is plain; because each of these having but
one simple , or one Member of Generation, could be look'd upon as but one single Person.

“”In conformity to this, when we behold this one Member, we distinguish the Sex, and pronounce it a Man, or a Woman; or as the alins express it, and an Homme, Fmme; one Man, one Woman. For the same Reason. Man and Wife are said to be one Fle because united in that part which constitutes the sameness and individuality of each Sex.

“”And as there is but one Member of Generation, there is but one Body, so there can be but one Soul; because the said▪ Organ of Generation is the Seat of the Soul; and conse∣quently, where there is but one such Organ, there can be but one Soul. Set me here say, without injury to truth, that no Phylosopher, either of the past or present age, hath taken more pains to discover where the Soul keeps her residence, than the Plaintiff, the learned Martinus Sriblrus: And after his most diligent enquiries and experiments, he hath been verily prsaded, that the Organ of Generation is the true and only Seal of the Soul. That this part is seated in the middle, and near the Centre of the whole Body, is obvious to your Honour's
view. From thence, like the Sun in the Centre of the World, the eal dispenses her warmth and vital influenc▪ t the Brain glory in the Wisdom of the aged, the Science of the learned, the policy of the Statesman, and the In∣ention of the witty; the accidental Amusements and of the Soul, and mortal as the of them▪ It is to the ran of Generation that we awe man himself▪ there the Soul is employ'd in works Suitable to the dignity of her nature, and (as we may oils breeding over ages yet unborn.

“”We need not tell your Honour, that it has been the opini∣on of many most learned irines and Phylosephers, that the Sul, as well as Body, is produced traduc. This dctine has been defended by arguments irrefraga, and accounts for difficulties, without it, inexplicable. All which arguments conclude with equall strength, for the Soul's being seated in the organs of Generation. For since the whole Man, both Soul and Body, is there form'd, and since nothing can operate but where it is, it follows, that the Soul must reside in that individual place, where She exerts her generatir and plastic pow∣ers.

“”This our doctrine is confirm'd by all these Experiments, which conspire to prove the absolute dominion which that part hath over the whole Body. We see how ma∣ny women, who are deaf to the persuasions of the Elo∣quent, the insinuations of the Crafty, and the threats of the imperious, are easily governed by some poor unfurnish'd with the least art, but that of making immediate application to this Seat of the Soul. The impressions made by the Ear are so distant, and transmitted thro' so many windings, that they lose their Energy: But your honour, by immediately applying to the organ of generation, gets like a bold and wise Petitioner, who goes strait to the very throne and Judgment-Seal of the Monarch. And whereas it is objected that here are two Wills, and therefore different persons; we answer, if multi∣plicity of Wills implied multiplicity of Persons, there are few Husbands but what are guilty of Polygamy, there being in the same woman great and notorious diversi∣ty of Wills: A point which we shall not need to insist upon before any married person, much less of your Honour's Experience.

“”Thus we have made eed our first and principal point; That if the Wife of the Plaintiff, Lindamira-Indamora, hath but one Organ of Generation, she is but one individual Person, in the truest and most proper Sense of Individuality. And that the matter of Sad is so, we are willing to put up on a fair Trial by a ury of atrons, whom year Honour shall think fit to nominate and appoint, to inspect the Body of the said Lindamira-Indamora.

“”Secondly, We are to prove, that tho' Lindamira-Indamora were two individual Persons, consisting each of a Soul and Body, yet, if they have but one Organ of Generation, they can constitute but one Wie. or, from whence can the Unity of any thing be denominated, but from that which constitutes the Essence or principal use of it? Thus, if a knife or hatche have but one blade, though two handles, it will properly be denominated but one knife, hatche; in as much as it hath but one of that which constitutes the Essence or principal Use of a knife or hatche. So if there were not only one, but twenty Supposita Rationalia with one common Organ of Generation, that one System would only make
one Wife. Upon the whole, let not a few heads, legs, or arms extraordinary, bias your Honour's Judgment, and de∣prive the Plaintiff of his legal property: In which right our Client is so strongly fortified, that allowing both the former Prepositions to be false, and that there were two persons, two Bodies, two Rational Souls, yea, and two Organs of Generation, yet would it still be plain in the third place.

“”That the Defendant, Prince Ebn-Hai-Pa-Wa, can have no Right to detain from the Plaintiff his lawfully wedded Wife, Lindamira. For, abstracting from the priority of the marriage of our Client, by which it would seem he acquired a property in his Wife and all other matter inseparably anner'd unto her, it is evident Prince Ebn-Hai-Paw-Waw, by his Marriage to Indamora, could never acquire any property in Lindamira; nor can produce any Cause why both of them should live with himself, rather than with the other? Therefore, we humbly hope your Honour will order the Body of our said Wife to be restored to us, and due Censure past on the said Ebn-Hai-Paw-Waw.

DIV2.P: Pennyfeather having thus ended his lading was thus answer'd by

DIV2.HEAD: Dr atherhead.

P.Q: “”I will not trouble your Honour with any unnecesary Preamble, or false lours of Elequence, which truth no need of, and which would prove too thin a for Falshood before the penetrating Eyes of your Honour. In answer therefore to what our learned brother, Dr. Pennyfeather, hath aserted, we shall labour to demonstrate,

“”First, That though there were but one Organ of Generation, yet are there two distinct persons. Secondly, That, although there were but one Organ of Generation, so far would it be from giving the Plaintiff any right to the Body of Indamora, the Wife of Ebn-ai-Pa-W, that it will subject the Plaintiff to the Penalty of nst, or of Bigamy.

“”Thirdly, We doubt not to prove that the said Lin∣damira-Indamora hath two distinct parts of Generation. And, first we will show, that neither the individual sence of Mankind, nor the seat of the Soul, doth re∣side in the Organ of Generation; and this first
from Reason. For unreasonable indeed must it be, to make that the Seat of the rational Soul, which alone sets us on a level with beasts; or to conceive, that the Esence of unity and individuality should consist in that which is the source of Discord and Division. In a word, what can be greater absurdity, than to affirm stiality to be the Essence of Humanity, Darkness the Centre of Light, and ilhiness the Seat of Purity? We could, from the authority of the most eminent Phi∣losophers of allages, confirm this our Assertion: few of whom ever had the Impudence to degrade this een, the rational Soul, to the very lowest and ilest apartment, or rather Sink of her whole Palace. But we shall produce still a greater Authority than these, to manifest that personal Individuality did subsist, when there was no such generative Carnality.

“”It hath been strenuously maintain'd by many ho∣ly Divines and particularly by Thomas Aquinas that our first Parents, in the state of Innocence, did in no wise propagate their Species after the present common manner of men and beasts; but that the pro∣pagation at that time must have been by Intuition,
of Ideas, or some pure and spiritual manner, suitable to the dignity of their Station. And the were distinguish'd in that State, yet it is plain it was not by parts, such as we have at present; since if our first Parents had any such, they must have known it; and it is written, that they discover'd them et till after the Fall; when it is probable those parts were the immediate Exerecence of Sin, and only grow forth to render them fitter companions for those beasts among which they were driven.

DIV2.P:
It is a maxim in Phylosophy, that generatio ius st erius; whence it is apparent that the Pa∣ra disaical Generation was of a different nature from ours, free from all corruption and Trbecillity, This is farther errebrated by the authority of those Doctors of the Church who have asserted, that before the Fall, Adam was ndew'd with a continual uninterrupted Faculty of Generation, which can be explain'd of e other than of that Intuitire Ge∣neration abovesaid: Since it is well known to all, the least skill'd in Anatomy, that the present (male) part of Generation is utterly incapable
of this continual Faculty.
DIV2.Q: “”We come new to our second point, wherein the ad∣vocate for the plaintiff a that if there were two persons, and one Organ of Generation, this Sys∣tem would constitute but one Wife. This will put the Plaintiff still in a worse Condition, and render him plainly guilty of Bigamy, Rap, or Incest. For if there be but one such Organ of Generation then both the persons of Lindamia and Indamera have an equal property in it, and what is Indamera's properly cannot be dispos'd of without her consent. We therefore bring the whole to this short Issue; whether the Plaintiff. Martinus Scriblerus had the consent of Indamera, or not▪ If he hath had her consent, he is guilty of Bigamy; if not, he is guilty of a Rape, or Incest, or both.

“”The Dependant, Prince n-Hai-aw-Waw, having been lately baptiz'd; hath with singular medisty abstain'd from consummation with his said Wife, untill he shall be satisfied from the opinion of your Honour, his learned Judge, how far in Law and Conscience he may proceed; and therefore he▪
cannot affirm much, nor positively, as to the structure of the Organ of Generation of this his Wife Indamera. Yet make we no doubt, that it will upon inspection appear, that the said Organ is distinct from that of in∣damira: whereupon we to hear the report of the jury of. atrons▪ appointed to inspect the Body of the said Gentlewoman.

“”And if the matter of give me your Honour's permission to repeat what hath been said by the advo∣cate for the Plaintiff; to wit, that Martinus Scriblerus, Batchelor in Physick, by this his Marriage with Linda∣mira, could in no wise acquire any property in the Body of ndamera, nor shew any Cause why this duplicated Wife Lindamira-Indamera, should abide with him, rather than with the Dependant, Prince En-Hai-aw-aw of .
DIV2.P: The Jury of Matrons having made their Report, and it appearing from thence that the parts of Generation in Lindamira and Indamera were distinct, the Judge time to deliberate, and the next Court-day he spoke to this effect.

DIV2.P: This Sntence pleas'd neither party; and Martin appeal'd from the Consistory to the Arches, but they confirm'd the Sentence of the nsistery.

It was at last brought before a Commission of Delegates;
who having weigh'd the Case, revers'd the Sentence of the inferior Courts, and disannull'd the marriage, upon the fellowing Reasons, “That allowing the manner of ehabitation enjoin'd to be practicable (though highly inconvenient) yet the being at all times equal in both Husbands and both Wives, and at the same time impossible in more than one; two persons could not have a right to the entire posses∣sion of the same thing, at the same time; nor could one s enjoy his property, as to dear another from the use of his, who has an equal right. So much as to the pei; and as to the m ad impossible.” Therefore the Lords, with great Wis∣dom, dissolv'd both Marriages, as proceeding upon a natural, as well as legal Absurdity.

DIV1.HEAD: CHAP. XV.
Of the Session of Martinus and some Hint of his Travels
DIV1.P: This affair being thus unhappily terminated, and become the whole talk of the Town; Martinus, unable to support the Affection, as well as the many disagree∣able Consequences, resolv'd to quit the Ringdom.

But we must not here neglect to mention, that du∣ring the whole course of this process, his cntinual Attendance on the Courts in his own Cause, and his invincible Curiosity for all that past in the Causes of others, gave him a Wonderful insight into this branch of Learning, which must be confess'd to have been so improved by the Moderns, as beyond all Comparison to exceed the ancients. From the day his first Bill was filed, he began to collect Reports; and before his Suit was ended, he had time abundantly sufficient to complite a very considerable Column. His anger
at his ill success caus'd him to destroy the greatest part of these Reports; and only to preserve such, as discover'd most of the and Fatility of the Practice. These we have some hopes to recover, if they were only mislaid at his Removal; if not, the world will be enough instructed to lament the les, by the only one new publick, viz, The ase of Stradling and Sles, in an action concerning certain black and white Horses,

We cannot wonder that he contracted a violent ver∣sion to the aw, as is evident from a whole Chapter of his Travels. And perhaps his Disappointment gave him also a Dis-inelination to the Fair Sex, for whom on some occasions he does not express all the Respect and admiration possible. This doubtless must be the Reason; that i no part of his we find him ee'd by any strange Princess; er have we he least account that he ever relaps'd into this Pas∣sion, except what is mentioned in the Introduction, of the Spanish' Lady's Phenomenon.

Memoirs on the contrary cries out, “”Happy, thrice happy day! which dissolv'd the Marriage of the great Scriblerus! be celebrated in every Language, learned and unlearned! let the Latin, the Greek, the Arabian; the Copic, let all the Sengues of many languag'd men, ay of animals, be employ'd to resound it! since to this we owe such immense discoveries, not only of Oceans, Centiments, Islands, with all their Inhabitands, minute, gigantic, mortal and immortal, but these yet mere enlarg'd and astonishing Views, of worlds, Phylosophical, Physical, moral, intelligible and unintelligible!
